thread.title: Thornton brush fire extinguished; dangerous blazes elsewhere
thread.title_full: Thornton brush fire extinguished; dangerous blazes elsewhere - The Denver Post

author: Kieran Nicholson
title: Thornton brush fire extinguished; dangerous blazes elsewhere
text:
A brush fire, which destroyed several abandoned outbuildings and involved a wood pile, was put out Tuesday afternoon by several fire departments including Thornton.
The fire was reported around 2:45 p.m. in the area of East 152nd Avenue and Monaco Street, said Chad McCollum, a Thornton Fire Department spokesman.
The fire burned about 3.5 acres, there were no injuries and no residential structures were threatened, McCollum said.
Unseasonably warm, dry weather along the Front Range is a raising concerns about the threat of wild fires.
"Anytime it's hot and dry, weed fires and grass fires are a concern," McCollum said. "Fortunately, there wasn't a lot of wind and that helped us out."
Firefighters from Brighton and North Metro helped extinguish the Thornton brush fire. The cause of the fire is under investigation.
To the north and east, several large, destructive wildfires burning on prairie lands have destroyed more than a dozen homes, killed livestock and forced evacuations over the past few days.
Fires with volcano-like smoke plumes visible for miles around have broken out from the Rockies almost to the Mississippi River.
Ample rain during the spring and summer made matters worse by encouraging prairie grass to grow into deep, thick wildfire fuels.
"All they needed was a spark," said Kelly Allen, a National Weather Service fire program manager in Riverton, Wyoming. "Now they're finally burning. The fuel bed is almost continuous."
